text: The newcomers in the schoolyard were not necessarily what you would imagine newcomers to be. They weren't shy, insecure or anxious, they weren't trying to make friends or get on with the important people, in fact they didn't even seem interested in identifying the important people at all. The two newcomers in the schoolyard - a pair of twins who, as the rumor mill quickly spread, went by the unimaginative names Jane and John - acted as if they owned the school, rather than as if they had joined as strangers at the beginning of the new school year.

Under normal circumstances, Noel wouldn't have minded. He had seen his foster sister Cara being bitched at by this Jane, but he knew Cara could fight back. Apart from her, he had no special friends at school, and no other siblings either. His other foster siblings were either too young or too flashy - or just too stupid - to go to school here. So there was no one he needed to protect from the new kids. Jane and John, with their arrogant behavior, would have left him completely untouched if they hadn't been on the same bus home, and if they hadn't stupidly had the same bus stop.

It was actually surprising that such a brother and sister would travel by bus at all and not have a car at their disposal. Noel instinctively suspected a story behind it, something about bad behavior and punishments. But he wasn't curious; curiosity had only ever got him into awkward situations. He preferred to keep a low profile, and since most people gave him a wide berth, that usually worked out quite well. So it really was exceptionally bad luck that Jane and John noticed him at all.

And the reason they did so was because they were the last to board the bus, where Cara and he had occupied the backmost seat, as they had done every day for the last three years. The only stupid thing was that Jane and John obviously wanted to claim this seat for themselves.
‘Oh, look, John,’ fluted blonde Jane, ‘the cool kids have picked our seats!’

Cara, who had already clashed with Jane, literally bared her teeth. Noel knew very well that it was better not to mess with Cara. Basically, any sensible teenager should have realized that with her punk rock outfit, dyed hair and self-piercings. He, on the other hand, leaned back and took a closer look at the newcomers for the first time.

Jane and John actually looked remarkably similar - both with full, honey-blonde hair, a rather narrow face with a long nose and closely spaced eyes. They weren't unattractive, in their own way, but something about them made Noel's antennae suddenly stand up. There was something different about these two.
‘You sit in our seats, children,’ Jane said sweetly, ‘be good and clear them.’
‘No,’ Cara returned just as sweetly, ‘get lost, old bitch!’
Jane clicked her tongue.
‘Oh, what a choice of words,’ she said reproachfully, ‘John?’

Her brother's hand suddenly shot out, grabbed Noel's chin and bent his face upwards. He immediately pulled away again, but it was possible that John had let go even faster himself. His eyes widened for a moment. Jane gave him an irritated look.
‘You have a very cute boyfriend, little punk,’ she whispered, ‘even if your bad influence is clearly visible. Bad choice of color, sweetie. Too bad about your beautiful eyes!’
Cara stood up. This had been a sore point with her for years, and that's why everyone usually let it slide.
‘Leave my brother alone,’ she hissed.
‘What else?’ sneered Jane, ‘shouldn't someone tell him that no one likes old men? What's with the white? Do you think it's cool to dye your hair like that, you poor wretch?’

Noel pulled one leg under him, partly because it made it clear that he had no intention of getting up, and partly because he knew from experience that he could kick more easily with the other. Cara hissed like a snake, but he beat her to it by simply saying, ‘I was born this way.’

For the rest of the bus, all schoolchildren who had been sharing their fate of the long journey for some time, all children who knew where he and Cara came from, this was no surprise. If you were a foster child from a large family and also blessed by nature with white hair - no, not white-blond, but really white - then at some point everyone knew you. Everyone knew he was Noel, currently the oldest foster child of Cara's parents, whose name, according to legend, came from the fact that he had been abandoned on Christmas Eve. He had heard all the jokes about Santa Claus long before he started secondary school. The other children had heard them too, several times. And they also knew how sensitive Cara was about him, even when he remained perfectly calm. She was volatile enough for both of them - not surprising when you were the only biological child of a couple who tried to save every problem child within reach.

The reactions were correspondingly anticlimatic. Jane laughed shrilly and said, ‘What?’ turning around mockingly and apparently waiting for applause. But instead, the children in the other seats just stared at her, or rather, they stared at Cara with that mixture of morbid fascination and concern that you would see in a car accident.
This reaction obviously sent Jane into a tailspin.
John, on the other hand, who apparently hadn't been paying much attention to the little exchange, sniffed his fingers and said thoughtlessly, ‘Your brother smells funny.’
That was too much for Cara.

The bus driver finally had to stop, drag Jane forward to a free row and hand her a handkerchief for her scratched cheek and bloody nose before he snapped at Cara: ‘Just because I appreciate your parents so much, little girl, you can stay on board, understand? I don't want to hear any more!’ John, who had probably only been prevented from successfully taking part in the scuffle by the cramped conditions of the bus, followed his beaten sister with a baleful look. Either way, the back row remained theirs: Cara, the notorious fury with the short fuse, and him, the foundling with the white hair.
He smelled funny, John had said. From that moment on, Noel knew he'd better stay away from Jane and John.

That wasn't so easy because, as they soon discovered, they were direct neighbors. But apart from them, Roger, the beefy son of the next farm who had a secret crush on Cara, and Melina, his little sister who hated Cara, got off the bus at the last stop. Roger stopped demonstratively, making it clear that he would not tolerate any physical attack on Cara, and Melina did her bit by grabbing Jane's hand, pulling her away and saying loudly: ‘Don't put up with that scum! They're the last ones here in the village, oh, in the whole county, everyone can tell you that! It's pure chaos at home and their parents are terrible hippies!’

Cara grimaced again, but she let Melina get away with it, partly because she knew she couldn't mess things up with Roger, and partly - well, partly because Melina wasn't entirely wrong. There really was chaos at home, no matter how hard her parents tried to keep things tidy, and unfortunately they were also a bit hippyish. Oliver and Sandra, as even their biological daughter called them, currently had seven foster children to look after, the youngest of whom was only a few months old, and the most difficult, Billie, was in need of round-the-clock care despite being ten years old. There were also the children with behavioral problems - Kevin, Mona and Lena - and the pre-school children - Brian and the aforementioned baby Lotti. Noel, the oldest foster child at fifteen, and Cara, who was almost the same age, tended to float along. Parental attention was hard to come by in their home. Noel personally didn't think he lacked it. However, he was pretty sure that Cara lacked it, and that it was also why she rebelled in her appearance, even though she behaved herself at home. And he believed that her relationship with him made up for her parents' lack of attention to a certain extent. Cara had adopted him from the moment he had first come into this chaotic household, from a no less, if differently chaotic, foster home where his last foster parents had returned him. It had been six years since then, and he had seen enough difficult children and teenagers come and go, short-term fosterlings from dramatic circumstances, foundlings or orphans like him who had been through more stages than they had years, children with problems, neglected children, children who blossomed under care and a safe haven, children who wet the bed, children who threw stones at others, and, and, and. So far, Oliver and Sandra had always managed to stay on top of things somehow. This is probably why they were always one of the first ports of call for the local authorities when accommodation was urgently needed for an emergency.

Naturally, however, there were always some nasty problems that had to be solved by Oliver and Sandra, and Cara and Noel felt the same way: parents struggling to find a safe place for a child couldn't be told that a strange boy on the bus had said that they smelled funny - especially as it wasn't the worst insult Noel had ever had to listen to in his life, nor was it the most original.
It was simply the one that scared him the most so far.

‘You don't smell funny,’ Cara grumbled to him on the short walk from the bus stop to the spacious old villa on the edge of the forest where they lived, ‘well, at least no weirder than the other boys. Maybe you even smell better. I think your hair smells good. Did you steal my shampoo?’
That came extremely close to a compliment from Cara, and he smiled.
‘I don't use girls' shampoo,’ he defended himself, ‘I stole Oliver's. Or was it Kevin's? His mother unloaded a whole bad conscience box last weekend.’
Kevin's mother took drugs, which was the reason why she kept losing her son. She was currently in rehab, hence the outbursts of guilty conscience and financially viable gifts.
‘The moss green stuff?’ asked Cara, ‘didn't that come from Billie's grandmother?’

Billie's grandmother was the paragon of bad conscience par excellence. Even on the verge of needing care, she was unable to look after her only grandchild, whose irresponsible mother had drunk her into fetal alcohol syndrome in utero before dying of liver failure. At the moment, it was about finding a long-term place for Billie to stay. The authorities, who wanted to keep Oliver and Sandra, did not think it advisable to leave such a costly child permanently with a constantly changing extended family, and Oliver, seeing the deep circles under Sandra's eyes, seemed to agree more and more. But that didn't solve where Billie should go, and until that was resolved, Sandra was bitterly determined to keep Billie. They didn't want to mess things up with Sandra any more than they wanted to mess things up with Cara. And they could only come up with reasonable arguments to a limited extent, such as the fact that they had already taken on enough. Alongside Kevin, whose ADHD was not treated with medication, even little Brian was comparatively quiet. Mona and Lena, the thirteen-year-old twins, made up for this: Mona suffered from anorexia and Lena from third-degree obesity. It seemed as if one was eating for both of them, and that naturally caused disputes.

The closer Cara and Noel got to the house, the louder they could hear their foster siblings. It was never quiet with them, never. It hadn't been quiet before either. The children hadn't been called Billie and Kevin, or Mona and Lena, but they had caused just as much commotion. To Sandra's secret sorrow, not one of them had made it to secondary school. Noel silently suspected that Sandra believed it was only thanks to him that her biological daughter had not gone the way of the others. He, on the other hand, was firmly convinced that Cara would have done everything she could to distance herself from the most difficult of her housemates, even without him.
Someone was yelling. No, two of them. That wasn't unusual, someone was almost always shouting. So it was good that her house was so big and remote. Cara stopped suddenly.

‘Sometimes I really wonder,’ she said, ‘if my parents hadn't had such trouble getting me, would all this even exist?’ And then she gave Noel a guilty look, because if Oliver and Sandra hadn't believed for a long time that they would never have biological children, then he, Noel, wouldn't be here either.
He knew that, looped his arm through hers and pulled her on.
‘Probably not,’ he said with a shrug, ‘then you'd have siblings like Jane and John. Wouldn't that be nice?’
Cara hissed involuntarily before laughing at him. They opened the door and were inside the chaos of home. It always crashed over them like a wave.

Noel couldn't fall asleep that night. Like Cara, he had a single room on the top floor of the house, far away from the younger children who needed attention. He had been given this as soon as Oliver and Sandra had realized that the quiet, white-haired boy, whom they had only taken in because he had suffered so much among the other children in the home due to his strange hair - Sandra had a real helper's syndrome and a flair for the difficult cases - was not at all conspicuous apart from this one peculiarity. It was crowded on the lower floors at the time, and the upstairs was frowned upon because of the long walk to the house bathrooms and because one of the girls who lived here at the time claimed to have seen a ghost there.
Noel was not afraid of ghosts. He had been called one himself often enough.

As Noel voluntarily moved into the small east room, Cara immediately claimed the opposite west room for herself. And as they were practically the same age, Sandra's argument that her daughter was still too small didn't count, of course. In the years that followed, Oliver even managed to raise enough money to install a tiny bathroom between their rooms and the stairs, so that they had their own realm in this respect too. The fourth door on the floor opened onto the large, unfinished attic, which Sandra used to dry her laundry in winter. The rooms therefore not only had the advantage of being far away from the hustle and bustle and too small for a second bed - making them the only single rooms in the house - but also a large playground for rainy days that belonged to them alone. When they were smaller, they set up a kind of cave between the boxes and skylights. As they got older, this was converted from a cave into a place to chill out and listen to music. Cara got her first piercing here under Noel's worried gaze with the help of an ice cube, mirror, lighter and a sewing needle. It bled so terribly that she had to throw her blanket away afterwards and promised to get her next piercings in other places. She did - behind the school gym, this time by her then crush, a punk - behind the hedge of the neighbor's house when it was still unoccupied, in front of John and Jane - and once even in the woods under an oak tree, because for some reason she thought it was significant. Sandra always sighed when her daughter came home with new holes in her face or ears, disinfected them and gave a lecture on life-threatening infections, which Cara stoically and deafly endured. She offered to pierce Noel's ears too, saying that she knew a thing or two about piercings, but he turned her down with the same words he had used to reject the punk rock jeans and chain belt - he was freak enough already.
‘Then dye your hair at last!’ Cara had argued angrily.

He was her best friend and she couldn't stand it when someone called him a freak, not even when he did it himself. Noel then let her in on the reason why his last foster parents had given him up, which, as far as he knew, only Oliver and Sandra still knew about. Neither of them ever approached him with any dye packs.

Other members of the house were already doing this, some with friendly intent, some with mockery. No one was successful, because no one knew what Noel knew: the coloring didn't last. After a week at the latest, he would be white again, white as an old man. He would rather let the others think he was too proud of his kinky hair than reveal to them how kinky it really was.
Old men could dye their hair, everyone knew that.
Noel's hair resisted all attempts.

He was a freak. He knew that. He only had the fact that Cara defended him and that there were enough other freaks around him to thank for the fact that he had remained so unmolested for so long. Of course, it helped that he didn't stand out otherwise. He was an average student in all subjects. He was friendly, but reserved. He didn't mess with anyone, but he didn't let anyone get close to him either.

He was called Noel because someone had been so afraid of an infant with a wild mass of white hair that they had put this child in a baby hatch one Christmas Eve. He didn't even know whether this was a legend or really true.
He was a freak. And now this boy, this neighbor named John, had noticed that there was something more to him than just a freak of nature. He smelled funny to John.

Noel could have dismissed this as a simple insult - of course you could hit a teenager like that, especially a foster child growing up in a chaotic household. But John hadn't known where he lived, who he was. And he knew he didn't smell strange. After all, Cara's wrinkled nose had been making sure he showered every day for years and changed his laundry, which was always clean thanks to the industrial washing machine downstairs.
Nevertheless, John said he smelled funny.
Noel was inclined to believe him.
But the question that then arose was - why did John notice?
Was John also a freak in the end?

On nights like this, when he couldn't sleep, he sometimes crawled out through one of the skylights onto the front roof of the house. Apart from him and Cara, nobody knew about this hiding place - which certainly didn't apply to their little music room behind the boxes, no matter how tired Sandra always was - and they had both practically sworn a blood oath never to tell anyone about it when they discovered it years ago. The canopy was unsecured. No matter how alternative and open Cara's parents were, they would have had a fit fit fit fit for the stage if they had known that their children were out here, even at night. No, it was better to keep this secret, and that's why nothing was left outside that could give them away.

This was perhaps a mistake. Despite the warm day, the night was chilly and Noel began to feel cold. However, he couldn't quite bring himself to climb back in, so he was almost relieved when Cara came crawling out, dragging her comforter behind her.
‘Can't sleep either?’ she asked as she generously shared the warmth with him.
‘Hm,’ Noel said. Something inside him wouldn't let him openly admit that he was afraid of John's remark - not because it had been mean, but because it might have been true.

‘Why is Melina always so mean to you?’ he asked instead, ‘is she mad because Roger likes you? Would you like me to have a word with her?’ Perhaps it wouldn't hurt to have better allies with this brother and sister nearby.
Cara laughed out loud. When they were alone, she always laughed like that, not mockingly at all, but simply amused.
‘Of course, you lightning bolt,’ she said lovingly, ‘if you tell Melina to be nice to me, she'll change in an instant! She'll love me!’
Cara was never mean to him. Cara would never imply that his word carried so little weight with a twelve-year-old whom he had helped ride her bike for years. He frowned.
‘Melina likes me,’ he began carefully, not understanding.
Cara laughed again and shook her head.

‘Of course,’ she said, rolling her eyes, ‘and how she likes you! She has a crush on you, Noel! She's not jealous of me because of Roger, but because of you. And as long as you don't like little girls, you won't be able to do anything about her.’
‘Oh,’ Noel said, sobered and confused.
It was quiet for a while. Girls were never into him. Well, she was twelve, but his hair was still white and he was the freak.
‘Are you so surprised?’ Cara finally asked. He shrugged his shoulders.
‘It's never happened before,’ he murmured.
She grinned.

‘You should be able to hear yourself,’ she said, ‘compared to the rest of the proletariat in this town, you already speak like an academic. Of course she likes you. And of course it will happen more and more often now that you're no longer a dwarf.’
Until last winter, Cara had been half a head taller than him, but now it was the other way around. She had always teased him about it. He sighed.
‘Doesn't it bother you...?’
‘Noel, everyone knows your hair. They think it's a cool quirk now. Didn't you notice what was going on on the bus today?’

At least there had been enough going on in the bus that Cara had scratched Jane's face like a fury, precisely because of his hair. Or wait, no, it hadn't been about the hair, but about the other thing. About his smell.

‘You don't smell funny,’ she murmured, as if she had followed his thoughts, and nuzzled her head into the crook of his neck. A completely new idea came to him, one that scared him and was somehow also exciting.
‘Melina is jealous of you,’ he said gently, ‘because of me. What does she think?’
‘Probably because we secretly snog each other all day and only pretend to be siblings on the outside,’ she said after a moment.
‘And ... And have you ever ...?’
‘Thought about kissing you?’
Cara was much braver than he was. All the eloquence she had attributed to him seemed to have left him. He looked at her face, white in the moonlight, and nodded silently. Her eyes were thoughtful.
‘What if?’ she finally asked, ‘would you find it so bad?’
Kissing Cara? She was pretty, in her own special way, sure. It was just a thought that had never occurred to him before.
‘No,’ he said, ‘not at all.’
‘Want to try it out?’

Did he want to? Yes, sure - he was young and she was soft in his arms, not at all the little scraper he was used to. He leaned forward slowly, a little more, and then their lips touched. He had read and heard about it. A real kiss involved more than just the gentle touch of two mouths, and this felt as chaste as the kisses Sandra gave him on the forehead from time to time. So he tried a little more, opened his lips slightly, tapped his tongue against hers and had to force himself to do so.
Cara pulled back and wriggled out of his arms.
‘Oh no,’ she said, ‘no, that's really not possible. Oh man, Noel, I'm sorry. But it really feels like I'm kissing my brother! I know we're not related, but it feels like it!’
'Thank you,' he said, immensely relieved, 'I think it feels that way too. And I don't want to kiss my sister. I want to ...’ He broke off and grimaced.
She wrapped herself in her blanket and eyed him suspiciously.
‘Do you even want to kiss girls?’ she asked challengingly, ‘or are you more into boys?’
Roger ran through his head, or the new guy, John, and he broke out in a cold sweat.
‘Nah, neither,’ he said defensively, ‘I don't think I want to kiss anyone until I ... I don't know...’
‘Are you in love?’ she prompted, ‘or in love, for the academics among us?’
‘Curious,’ he confessed, blushing heavily.
Cara stared at him and then gave an unnamed snort.
‘So you're not curious enough about me to want to kiss me,’ she said, half amused, half offended.
‘Aren't you glad it's like this? Or are you curious enough about me to kiss me after all?’ he countered. She stared at him.

‘Nah,’ she grumbled, then slid back and offered him her blanket again, pressing her head back into the group between his shoulder and neck. He gratefully accepted the warmth of the blanket, and even more gratefully her warmth. He gave her a very gentle, chaste kiss on her hair.
‘I'm glad you're my sister,’ he whispered, ‘I wouldn't trade you for the world.’
‘Well, you're lucky,’ she said, ‘I'm not trading you in either, Noel. And don't worry, that John won't get too close to you. I'll make sure of that.’
He didn't say anything for a while. He wasn't sure if she hadn't already fallen asleep on that rickety canopy, in his arms, when he finally whispered: ‘And what if it's too late for that?’

Not far from them, in the nearby forest, something sounded like a howl, almost like a wolf howl. He knew that a few wolves had been released into the wild this spring on a trial basis, and that they could well find refuge in the large wooded area behind them, a completely natural occurrence that was harmless to humans. Nevertheless, a shiver ran down his spine.
And he could tell from Cara's sudden trembling under his fingers that she was far from asleep.

Cara began her offensive against John and Jane the next day, on the way to the bus stop. She intercepted Roger and Melina and said almost casually, scratching at the nail polish on her fingernails: ‘Hey, Roger. Don't you want to sit at the back with us? You can see all the idiots much better.’ She put her finger in her mouth and bit off a hangnail while Roger stared at her with wide eyes. Just as casually, Cara added: ‘And you, little one, we'll find a place for you too, won't we, Noel? You're getting big.’
Melina stared at Cara, just as stunned as her brother, although perhaps for different reasons. Cara gave Noel a shove with her elbow.
‘It's a good idea, isn't it, Noel?’ she said, ‘there are four seats at the back.’

Which she had defended tooth and nail until now. Noel had to force himself not to stare at her in bewilderment. But out of the corner of his eye, he saw the twins approaching, their blond hair blowing in the wind, and almost automatically he replied: ‘We should have done that long ago.’
Melina was practically beaming with the sun.

So, without thinking twice, Roger made sure that Cara and Melina got on the bus first, then Noel, then himself, and only at the end the visibly annoyed siblings. And so it was that the back row at this first stop was completely full. The twins' mood was not necessarily improved when the bus driver - the same one from the previous day - looked at them and said almost sympathetically: ‘Well, you two had better stay up here with me, hadn't you? Otherwise your fancy clothes will get a bit of a beating.’
Noel was sure he could see subtle steam rising from Jane's ears. This was certainly not how she had imagined this ride.

Cara didn't let up at school either. So far she had paid relatively little attention to people's opinions, which was certainly a good thing, because for many people she was the child from this strange extended family. But she was also the cool little punk who defended her opinions like a wildcat and whose compliments were as rare as a rainbow. Noel could see her leaving words in cleverly placed places throughout the morning - words of encouragement, words of appreciation, or criticism of John and Jane. It certainly helped that they hadn't made many friends the day before with their arrogant behavior. But Noel had never realized how influential Cara was in her year - and strangely enough, neither had he. Perhaps it was by projection on her part, perhaps because she was the only one to accept his words without comment, the only one to accept him completely, perhaps because she cleverly made it clear to the students that her foster brother was perhaps a freak with white hair, but he was her freak, had been for years, and he was something special. What Cara was doing there, he finally realized, was a tremendously clever image campaign that, while by no means making them the most popular sibling in the year, was possibly the coolest, and thus something Jane and John couldn't easily attack.

At the end of the school day, Noel, who looked at all this with more distance, realized that he obviously had friends he hadn't known about. He hadn't known that Mika, undisputedly the best artist in their class, a quiet, shy guy, had secretly drawn several pictures of him.

‘But not gay, man, or anything,’ Mika insisted when Cara dragged him in during the break and almost ordered him to show the pictures to Noel, ‘but just because you're kind of ... I don't know. It's a challenge to draw you without you looking like a girl. I mean ... Your ears ... And...’

‘I see what you mean,’ said Noel, flicking through the pad and impressed by the quality of the pictures, while thinking to himself that Mika was so gay, but so sure, and probably just as into him as Melina. He didn't say anything about that, however, because he was really impressed by the boy's talent. He finally turned the conversation to an animal drawing that had caught his eye the first time.
‘They're wolves, aren't they?’ he asked, ‘are they the ones from the forest?’
‘No, from the zoo,’ Mika confessed, ‘I've never seen the wolves in the forest. Do you really like my pictures?’
‘I think she's phenomenal,’ Noel said, and he was completely honest.

Nor had he expected Roger to join them not only on the bus, but also during the break. To Noel's secret relief, Melina did not yet dare to do so. But Roger, who had tried in vain to get Cara's attention, finally looked at Mika's drawings too, seemed genuinely amazed by his talent and praised them in his short, grumpy way. He had won both Cara's and Noel's hearts, and Mika's anyway.
So it was no longer a question of who sat in the back when they drove home.

Noel should have been relaxed; everything was fine. And yet, for some reason he couldn't sleep that night, for some reason he finally got up and climbed back out through the window onto the porch roof. This time, too, he had no blanket with him, as he belatedly realized, but Cara's soft snoring suggested that she would not be coming to his aid today.
Later he was glad about it.

He didn't see the man coming. He didn't know where he was coming from either, because although there were a few old, tall trees near the house, none of them were close enough to jump from a branch onto the canopy. And you could perhaps climb down from the canopy quickly, there were enough vines on the wall of the house, but if you climbed up, you would end up pulling yourself over the edge with a groan, as Noel knew from his own experience. The young man, however, jumped. He jumped out of nowhere and landed in an elegant crouch right in front of him, his hair shimmering in the moonlight, his eyes sparkling strangely. Noel backed up and froze.
‘Ah, little cousin,’ said the stranger.
Noel said nothing. What was he supposed to say? Who are you? Where are you from? It seemed unlikely that he would get any honest answers. The man grinned and dimples formed in his cheeks.
‘Little cousin,’ he repeated, ‘you're not thinking of running into the forest tonight, are you?’

Now he broke out in a sweat. He loved the forest, the only thing that really set him apart from Cara, and yes, sometimes he had walked through it on moonlit nights. But not now. Not now. The strange man tilted his head.

‘There are monsters outside,’ he whispered, ‘monsters. But you already know that, don't you? You'd do well to stay away. You're too young for them, little one, no match for them. They would tear you apart. Stay here, away from the forest. Everything will work out. Will you do that?’
He moved his head promptly, as if expecting an answer. Unable to help himself, Noel finally nodded.
‘Good boy, little prince,’ whispered the man, ‘we're keeping an eye on you!’ And with that sentence, he jumped back down from the canopy.
It took Noel several moments for his body to recover from the shock enough to be able to move. Of course, there was no one in the square in front of the house.
He strongly suspected that no one would have been there if he had looked down faster.

The stranger was not such a stranger to him after all, so he kept this incident to himself. All his life it had happened from time to time that among all the people who stared at him strangely because of his hair, there were also some who smiled mysteriously, as if they knew something, or even winked at him. The night hadn't been particularly bright, so he couldn't be entirely sure, but he thought he'd seen this young man before, or even more than once - always around the house, or in the woods, since he'd been living with Oliver and Sandra. And something, something he couldn't put his finger on, had always prevented him from talking about him, or any of the others.
He didn't do it this time either.

This fall, wolves became a problem. Unusual incidents occurred - hunters found extremely mangled carcasses, livestock were torn from the pasture, and although the wolves' supporters swore by their pair of wolves being at home in a completely different corner of the forest, people became restless. Noel had always felt very comfortable in the forest so far - as I said, the only thing that really set him apart from Cara, or rather, the only thing he did without her. Before this fall, he had loved roaming through the old forest, sitting under the huge trees and climbing one or two of them. He was the only one of Oliver and Sandra's children who had done this. Mona tended to go for long runs through the forest occasionally - she couldn't be seen and couldn't be forbidden to do so - but she stopped as soon as the first deer was killed. Noel himself didn't make a conscious decision, but when Oliver approached him and asked him to avoid the forest for the time being, he realized that he hadn't taken any walks there in a while. The young stranger had been right - he hadn't needed the warning.

Being neighbors with John and Jane made little difference to their routine. Cara and he were so involved in school and home duties that there was little time for extras anyway. John and Jane, on the other hand, didn't seem to make any effort to befriend the children of the village or even their immediate neighbors. Noel didn't know if they ever visited the forest, or if they were even aware of the growing plague. But the further the fall progressed, the worse it got. And then one day a forest worker was attacked and his throat torn apart. Needless to say, the wolf friends lost. A general hunt was declared and the forest was combed for days.
And Cara dragged Noel to Leonie.

Leonie was a casual acquaintance of Cara's, played guitar and was thinking about forming a punk band with her friends. They still needed a lead singer, and Cara, who loved punk rock, dragged Noel to her and her friends during the lunch break.
‘If you need a really cool lead singer,’ she claimed, ‘my brother is the best you can have!’

Noel broke out in a cold sweat. Sure, he could sing, one of his few talents. Sure, he sometimes did it with his family when it was surprisingly quiet enough for a campfire or something similar. But in a band, in front of strangers? Had Cara gone mad? Did she want to throw him under the bus?
‘I heard you in the choir,’ Leonie said thoughtfully, ‘the little solo was okay. But aren't you two a bit young?’

Leonie was in the year above him, and of course this was nothing that would have stopped Cara. With vehemence, charm and persuasiveness, she told Leonie that they were both about to turn sixteen, old enough for a band, and that their parents were open-minded, and that Noel had only not got the big solo back then because he didn't fancy that kind of school shit, and so on and so forth. With her torrent of words, she almost convinced Noel himself, and definitely Leonie.
‘We can give it a try,’ she gave in, ‘we always meet on Thursdays after school.’
‘Sounds great!’ said Cara with a broad grin.
‘We'll talk about that later!’ Noel hissed at her after they had left the group. Cara stopped immediately, turned to him and dug her finger into his chest.

‘You can sing!’ she said harshly, ‘and you know the lyrics. I'm right - you'd make a cool lead singer! Why do you always want to blend in with the background, Noel? In a punk band, no one will give a damn about your hair!’
‘But they won't give a damn if I'm a punk singer or not!’
‘Well, then you better be one, and a good one at that!’
Cara was like a force of nature when she was out and about like that.

But because he felt John's hostile looks on the drive home, because he knew why she was running this campaign, and because he heard wolves howling again at night and it woke him from his sleep, he dutifully turned up at Leonie's house on Thursday after school with Cara in tow. They had a drummer zeuger, a bass player and Leonie herself as guitarist, who also sang. Cara wanted to take over the second vocals, where Leonie needed support.

It got off to a slow, bumpy start. Noel had never been on stage before and was insecure, which, as is usually the case with him, manifested itself in extreme silence - certainly good for the coolness factor, but bad for a lead singer. He could literally feel Cara's half-angry, half-encouraging eyes on his back, and it was only for her sake that he finally sang his way through the first song.
Then there was silence. The bassist looked at him suspiciously and Leonie looked startled. Cara cleared her throat.
‘Noel,’ she said softly, ‘sing Boulevard of Broken Dreams. By Green Day, you know.’
‘I'm not sure if I can play it,’ said Frank, the bass player.
‘Are it a cappella, Noel,’ Cara said urgently, ‘just do it. I know you can do it. And the rest of you can just jump in. Please, everyone knows this song!’

‘I don't know...’ mumbled the bassist. But Leonie nodded and the drummer let out a few hesitant beats. Noel, who must have heard Cara play this song a thousand times, simply closed his eyes and did as she asked.

When he finished, he was aware of how quiet it was. Sure, Leonie had accompanied him, the drummer too, but the bassist had done almost nothing, and neither had Cara. He swallowed and braced himself for the criticism.
‘Man,’ the bassist finally said hesitantly, ‘for real, man. I think your voice is too good for punk.’
‘What?’ Noel said in disbelief.
Cara, that little beast, giggled. Frank turned bright red.
‘Well, man, I'm just saying!’ he said, ‘Punk rock is actually for all those who can't really sing and still make music ... or so I've heard ...’
‘I think that's an insult,’ Leonie said, not unkindly, ‘but Frank's right. Noel, heavens! We've been in the choir together for years and I had no idea! You sing like...’
‘Like a young god?’ Cara grinned. Leonie looked at her almost punitively.

‘More like a being from another world,’ she said coolly, ‘the way I always imagined Legolas would sing if he ever tried his hand at punk rock. Your hair is far too short for that, of course. Elf prince, if you want to be our lead singer, you need to get a bit rougher!’
‘Legolas is an Elf, not an elf,’ grumbled Sam, the drummer, ‘and why the women always go for that sissy ...’
‘Are we really going to talk about mythical creatures?’ Frank asked incredulously.
‘I'm too soft for you?’ Noel said, unexpectedly offended, ‘not rough enough? Well, then ...’

And he threw himself into one of Cara's favorite songs with gusto, pouring in all the suppressed anger, frustration and rage that had built up in him over the past few days. This time they all played in the end, and Frank grinned at him.
‘Okay, fine,’ he said, ‘we might just have to educate you a little ...’
‘Or we need to rework our style a bit,’ Leonie interrupted him with shining eyes, ‘seriously guys, this will get us a gig! For sure! We just need to practise!’
‘And maybe we can play our own songs,’ Cara intervened, ‘I already have a few ideas! I have the lyrics, I just need the sound!’
So it was that Noel found himself singing in a punk rock band from one day to the next.

Of course, not everything went smoothly. They were indeed right that his voice wasn't rough enough for a punk. Whenever he really sang, the style of their songs changed completely. Leonie, who searched for a long time, finally described his voice as haunting, something she could never adequately translate. But they found a way to integrate it into their program, much faster than he would have ever thought. He was best able to embody the punk rocker when he shared the lead with Leonie, which of course she liked. They practiced diligently, and when Leonie announced that she had secured a gig for them a whopping four weeks after their first rehearsal, Noel could hardly believe it. They didn't care that it was taking place in one of their uncle's pubs and therefore couldn't really count as a gig.
‘After all, you're sixteen now, Noel,’ Leonie said with a critical look, ‘my uncle insists. Cara, you really need to hold back.’
‘Noel is actually younger than me,’ Cara claimed cheekily, ‘and I'll be sixteen next week. I'm getting a guitar for my birthday.’
‘I'm not younger than you,’ Noel grumbled, ‘and the guitar is a surprise from Oliver and Sandra. You should be surprised.’
‘You don't even know if you're younger than me,’ Cara replied.
‘My birth certificate says the first of November,’ he replied from above, ‘and yours says the fourteenth. So? I'm older.’
‘Pah,’ she said, but fortunately didn't insist any further.
Noel's birthday was a real thing - nobody knew him.

The legend, which he himself was not entirely sure was true, was that he had been deposited in the baby hatch on Christmas Eve and had therefore been baptized Noel. He would only find out if this was actually the case when he came of age, when he would have access to his own files, and assuming that this was what it said, of course. Perhaps he could find out sooner - a friendly question to Oliver and Sandra, or to his social worker, might have shed some light on the matter. But that wasn't really important to him. What was important was that he had been abandoned sometime in late December, and that he was no longer a newborn at that point. The pediatrician who had tried to determine his age had dated his birth to the beginning of November, and so, in the absence of any other evidence, he had become the first. Ever since Cara had heard the story, she had tried to make him believe he was younger. At first she wanted his birthday to be celebrated together with hers, and when she was refused, she claimed instead that he was actually younger than her. It was an old game and Noel let her get away with it.
At least she didn't tell Leonie why she was riding on it like that.

But between his birthday and the performance - the evening before Cara's - something else amazing happened: John and Jane disappeared. One day they didn't come to the bus, they weren't at school, and there were no lights on in the house next door. Of course, rumors spread immediately. Someone said they were on a trip around the world and were being looked after by a private tutor, someone else claimed they had stolen and were serving their sentence in prison. Noel could guess who had started the second rumor. He suspected something more like the first, perhaps less glamorous. The fact was, however, that the two of them were gone from one day to the next - and that no one knew for sure whether they would ever return.

Noel was secretly so relieved that he was surprised at himself. In view of this relief, their performance, which had previously seemed like a mountain in front of him, seemed easy to master. And they overcame it with incredible ease. It was over before he could get really scared, without anything going seriously wrong. It actually seemed as if it was much easier for him than he had ever thought.

‘There you go,’ said Cara with grim satisfaction and, with a big wink, convinced the barman to buy them a round of beer to celebrate. This of course improved the mood even more. The others were quick to rave about a great career.
‘Are you sure,’ Noel whispered to her between the first and second sips of his first beer, ‘that we're still doing this because of John and Jane?’
Cara looked up at him innocently.
‘John and Jane?’ she asked, ‘when have we ever done anything about those two bitches?’
He laughed and pulled her close, tousling her wild hair. He was so glad that she was his sister.
That night he didn't hear anyone howling in the forest.

John and Jane didn't come back, and the house next door remained unoccupied. That winter, they kept performing in Leonie's uncle's small pub and then, one Saturday night in February, they actually had their first big gig: they were the opening act in a club in town. The owner demanded written permission from Oliver and Sandra for Noel and Cara to be allowed on stage. He demanded it from everyone except Sam, who had just celebrated his eighteenth birthday, as they were underage. But with this permission, nothing stood in their way. Oliver even took time off work to attend the event, and although Cara grumbled about it and muttered something about parental alarm, Noel knew she was pleased. Attention was a rare commodity in their home.

Not everything went perfectly during this lift. Sam fluffed a solo with excitement and Cara missed a cue, but as they weren't particularly well known, Noel didn't think anyone but them had noticed. At least Oliver hadn't noticed, who was very proud of his daughter and foster son and even bought them a beer. Fortunately, he didn't notice that Cara was secretly having a few shots with Sam to celebrate the day. Oliver was blissfully happy when he drove her home - and so was Noel.

He was more than that. Cara stumbled into her bed after arriving home and fell asleep immediately, but Oliver put his hands on Noel's shoulders for a moment and told him how incredibly happy he was that Noel was a part of his family - not just a temporary foster child, but a real family member, as he put it. Noel knew that Cara had often urged her parents to finally adopt him. He also knew that it went against Sandra's philosophy to single out a single child among all her charges, but that night he believed that Oliver would have adopted him sooner rather than later. That pleased him, of course - everyone craved a home and acceptance, after all - but even though he smiled and said thank you, it wasn't the reason why, when he got to his room, he couldn't bring himself to go to bed.
He just couldn't sleep yet. Life was burning inside him.
And so he didn't undress, but crept over to the window to the canopy and climbed out. Without giving it much more thought, he shimmied down the old vine, landed silently on the ground and ran off.

He ran the short distance to the forest, into the old forest. The moon shone brightly through the bare branches, a little snow lay on the ground, and Noel ran, just like that, out of sheer joy, because he could, because he was allowed to, because the forest was his again. He imagined he could hear little voices in the frozen land, soft and enthusiastic, eyes shining in the dark.
He loved his life that night and spread his arms wide as he ran to feel it.

He loved it even more when spring came. Cara had fallen head over heels for Sam and started an affair with him, which may have been good for her musical progress - she was determined to become the songwriter for her little band and was studying guitar hard - but otherwise cut into the time she would otherwise have spent with Noel. He came home from school alone more and more often because she was still staying with Sam, and more and more often, because it was too boring without Cara, he spent his free hours in the woods.
He knew it was only a matter of time before he met the young man again.

When it happened, it was sudden. He was once again walking along, intoxicated by the awakening greenery, the increasing warmth, the small flowers, when the stranger fell from the sky. To be more precise, he didn't fall from the sky, but jumped from a considerably high branch of one of these giant trees directly onto the path in front of him.

Yes, Noel knew him. He knew the tousled brown hair, the pointed chin, those forest green eyes, that mischievous smile. He also knew it so well because he kept seeing some of these things in his own mirror. Little cousin, the stranger had called him.
‘Little cousin,’ he said now too, tilting his head, ‘I see you know that the forest is safe again.’
‘What's your name?’ Noel asked bluntly. After all, it wasn't worth stating the obvious.
The young man in front of him laughed.
‘Ah,’ he said, ‘I'm glad you're not a scaredy-cat, little one. Shall I tell you my name? But yes, I think I'm allowed to. One at least. Call me Robin.’
‘Robin,’ Noel repeated, ‘I'm...’
But he was rudely interrupted.
‘I know who you are,’ Robin said emphatically, ‘better than you do. Don't give me that silly name they've put on you. I know your real one.’
‘Is that so?’ Noel asked with interest, ‘then you know who abandoned me? Who my parents are?’
Robin puffed through his nose.

‘You weren't abandoned, you were given to another home,’ he said firmly, ‘a safer one than the one you were born into. And yes, I know your parents' names. But that's one of the things I'm not allowed to tell you. You're still too young and vulnerable, little one. Here, in this forest, you are safe. We'll look after you. It has to stay that way for a few more years.’
‘In which you don't want to tell me who I am, who my parents were and why you're looking after me, do you?’ Noel stated.
The young man laughed appreciatively.

‘Right, my little prince,’ he said, almost whispering, ‘right. You know we always looked out for you, right? We stayed hidden, as it was decided. But last fall, I had to warn you. I didn't know if you were wise enough to stay away from the monsters, and I couldn't take any chances. Now I think you're old enough to get to know a few of us. Flora is already quite curious about you. I'm sure she'll be here soon.’
Gradually, Noel thought, enough was enough. Did he know whether the man wasn't just crazy in the end?
‘Who are you?’ he asked emphatically.
Robin grinned.
‘Who do you think, my little one?’ he repeated mockingly, ‘we are yours!’
And with that, in one leap, he was high up, back in the branches of the trees, several meters above the ground and disappeared into the tangle of leaves.
Noel stood back, startled.

It was too abstruse, too confused for him to share with anyone, to hope that anyone would understand him. If he had told Cara or even Sandra and Oliver about it, they would have dismissed the stranger as a lunatic and, in the worst case, kept Noel away from the forest. He didn't even know why he couldn't believe this - why it even seemed normal to him, almost expected, and not abstruse and confused.
It seemed as if he had just been waiting for this, or at least a part of him, the part that was different.

He was a freak, and much more than just in terms of his unusual hair. He knew that, so it came as no surprise to him that his own were creatures who could jump from a standing position onto meter-high branches.
Or they were half-naked women, covered more with rows of flowers than fabric, who approached him one day in a clearing.

If he had been Cara, or Mona, who had run through the forest earlier, he would have blushed and perhaps even run away. Cara, at least, would have said a few sharp words. But Noel was the freak. He just stood still.

The woman was barely covered, but she was also extraordinarily beautiful and, above all, had a wonderful smile. She approached him, slowly, carefully, kindly. She gently placed her hand against his cheek and looked deep into his eyes. In this forest, nothing surprised him any more.
‘Let me guess,’ he blurted out, ‘you're Flora - the one Robin told me about.’
The woman's smile became radiant.
‘Oh Robin, the rogue,’ she said, ‘but yes, I am Flora. I'm one of the ones watching over you. And I'm so glad to finally get to know you properly!’
‘Ah,’ Noel said, not a little nervously - after all, she was practically naked! - ‘And what exactly did you have in mind - by getting to know her, I mean?’
She took a few steps back, settled gracefully on a patch of moss and tapped the spot next to her.

‘Sit down,’ she said invitingly, ‘and tell me. I haven't been allowed to visit you in your sleep for years. Is that little girl still around? And what are the people who look after you like? What's that music you always listen to?’

‘You visited me in my sleep?’ he asked in amazement as he crouched down next to her. Not only did she look seductive, she also smelled good. Robin had smelled of forest and earth, but she mainly smelled of flowers. She shrugged her shoulders. A garland of flowers slipped and magically stuck in time over her chest.
‘When you were little,’ she said, ‘we made sure nothing happened to you while you slept. I always enjoyed watching you sleep. You were so small and innocent.’
‘Indeed,’ said Noel, who found it strangely reassuring that someone had been watching over his sleep - and then, of course, also very frightening to be watched while he slept.
‘But you're not doing that anymore, are you?’ he asked to be on the safe side.
Flora shook her head regretfully.

‘As soon as the house was deemed safe, we were all banished from it,’ she sighed, ‘you got restless when we got too close to you. You can sense us, can't you? That's only normal, my prince. You belong with us.’
‘Will you tell me who we are?’ he asked without much hope.
As expected, she laughed and said no.

‘Oh no,’ she said, ‘but don't worry. The day will come when you'll know for yourself. At least the monsters who got too close to you are gone. What a fear I had for you! Luckily Robin was able to chase them away!’

In a strange, abstruse way, it all made sense to Noel. And so he didn't mind answering Flora's curious questions - about Cara, whom she had obviously taken to her heart, but of whom she said regretfully that she was too suspicious of them and that Noel therefore shouldn't tell her anything - he wouldn't anyway, Cara would declare him crazy - about Sandra and Oliver, of whom she was latently jealous - and about the punk rock that she didn't understand, no matter how hard he tried. The afternoon progressed quite quickly and at some point she stood up.

‘No, stay seated,’ she said with a smile as he also tried to get up, ‘this is my time and I want to make the most of it. I want you to meet two of my daughters. They're already dying to. May? Berry? You may come now!’

To Noel's surprise, two young girls emerged from the shadows opposite, both delicate and petite, and yet so different. One was blonde and milky white, the other red-haired and tanned. Both had long, unruly hair - curls on the redhead, straight on the blonde, and both wore nothing but soft sleeveless shirts that fell just below their knees.
‘Mai and Berry are so excited for you,’ Flora whispered in his ear, ‘you can trust them. They won't do anything that's forbidden!’

Noel was sixteen, and he had only ever kissed one girl in his life - Cara, on the porch of her house. From that point of view, no one in the world could have blamed him for not resisting when these two extremely graceful, sweet girls snuggled up to him, turned his head towards them, and first one, then the other, pressed their lips to his.
He didn't even notice how Flora disappeared.

He did not lose his innocence on this spring afternoon in the small clearing in the forest. This seemed to be one of the things that Mai and Berry - he didn't even mind their names - were not allowed to do. And yet he learned a great deal, about breathy kisses, about gentle fingers, about soft skin, about loving caresses and silky hair. When he finally went home, he realized that he could never tell Cara about this, or anyone else. They would all think he was crazy.

Maybe that was him too. Perhaps he dreamed up a fairytale world on his long, lonely afternoons in the forest, similar to Terabithia - with the only difference being that he was its only human inhabitant. But if that wasn't the case, if he wasn't dreaming - was he even human?
